places.name: Penzance
places.description: Penzance is a town, civil parish, and port in the Penwith district of Cornwall, and Davy's birthplace.

places.name: Bristol
places.description: A city in south-western England.

places.name: Wales
places.description: Wales is a country in southwest Great Britain known for its rugged coastline, mountainous national parks, distinctive Welsh language and Celtic culture.

persons.name: WilliamCoates
persons.description: Member of a family of Bristol wine merchants, visitor to the Medical Pneumatic Institution, and subscriber to various Bristol literary works. Later detained in France following the end of the Peace of Amiens.

persons.name: GeorgeHandel
persons.description: German-born composer who spent much of his life in Britain, and was buried in Westminster Abbey.

places.name: River Avon
places.description: The River Avon in central England flows generally south-westwards and is a major left-bank tributary of the River Severn.

persons.name: Jean-JacquesRousseau
persons.description: Swiss born French philosopher who wrote, among other things, on social inequality and education. His ideas were used widely during the French Revolution.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

places.name: Wales
places.description: Wales is a country in southwest Great Britain known for its rugged coastline, mountainous national parks, distinctive Welsh language and Celtic culture.

places.name: Ganges
places.description: The Ganges is a river in Asia running through India and Bangladesh. It is part of the third largest river on earth.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

places.name: Galilee
places.description: Galilee is a region located in northern Israel and southern Lebanon.

places.name: Ganges
places.description: The Ganges is a river in Asia running through India and Bangladesh. It is part of the third largest river on earth.

places.name: Mount's Bay
places.description: A bay on the English Channel coast of Cornwall, England, stretching from the Lizard Point to Gwennap Head.

places.name: Africa
places.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

places.name: Snowdon
places.description: The highest mountain in Wales.

places.name: Tintern Abbey
places.description: Tintern Abbey is a ruin found on the banks of the River Wye in Monmouthshire, Wales. It was the location of a poem by William Wordsworth, published in Lyrical Ballads, the second edition of which was proof-read by Davy.

places.name: Kynance Cove
places.description: Kynance Cove lies to the east of Mount's Bay in Cornwall, on the Lizard Peninsula.

places.name: Lizard Point
places.description: The Lizard is a peninsula of the southern coast of Cornwall. It is the most southerly point of the British mainland. The geology of the Lizard is complex: it contains some of Cornwall's oldest (Precambrian) rocks, as well as heavily metamorphosed rocks.

places.name: Mullion, Cornwall
places.description: Mullion is a village on the Lizard Peninsula, Cornwall.

places.name: Mount's Bay
places.description: A bay on the English Channel coast of Cornwall, England, stretching from the Lizard Point to Gwennap Head.

places.name: Lizard Point
places.description: The Lizard is a peninsula of the southern coast of Cornwall. It is the most southerly point of the British mainland. The geology of the Lizard is complex: it contains some of Cornwall's oldest (Precambrian) rocks, as well as heavily metamorphosed rocks.

places.name: Mullion, Cornwall
places.description: Mullion is a village on the Lizard Peninsula, Cornwall.

places.name: Gulval
places.description: A village in Cornwall, near Penzance.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

persons.name: FrancisHauksbee
persons.description: English natural philosopher best known for his work on electricity and electrostatic repulsion. FRSL

persons.name: JamesStodart
persons.description: British surgical instrument maker; experimented on steel with Michael Faraday. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesStodart
persons.description: British surgical instrument maker; experimented on steel with Michael Faraday. FRSL.

persons.name: FrancisHauksbee
persons.description: English natural philosopher best known for his work on electricity and electrostatic repulsion. FRSL

persons.name: Thomas (Tom)Wedgwood
persons.description: Youngest son of Josiah Wedgwood who became a close friend of Davy's. Together they published a paper which has been taken as marking the start of chemical photography.

persons.name: Joseph LouisProust
persons.description: French analytical chemist. Author of the 1794 paper 'Researches on Prussian Blue', in which he first set down the law of definite proportions, or Proust's law, as it is commonly known.

persons.name: Joseph LouisProust
persons.description: French analytical chemist. Author of the 1794 paper 'Researches on Prussian Blue', in which he first set down the law of definite proportions, or Proust's law, as it is commonly known.

persons.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
persons.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JosephBanks
persons.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society
works.author: Humphry Davy

places.name: Mumbai
places.description: Mumbai (formerly called Bombay) is a densely populated city on India’s west coast.

places.name: Bengal
places.description: Bengal is a historical geographical, ethnolinguistic and cultural term referring to a region in the eastern part of the Indian subcontinent at the apex of the Bay of Bengal. The region of Bengal proper is divided between the modern-day sovereign nation of Bangladesh and the Indian state of West Bengal.

persons.name: GeorgeFordyce
persons.description: Scottish physician, lecturer on medicine and chemist who worked in London. FRSL.

persons.name: George O'BrienWyndham
persons.description: From 1763 3rd Earl of Egremont. Very wealthy collector and agriculturalist who criticised some of Davy's work. FRSL.

persons.name: John BirdSumner
persons.description: Teacher at Eton College; later Bishop of Chester and Archibishop of Canterbury. FRSL.

persons.name: ArthurYoung
persons.description: Agricultural writer and Secretary to the Board of Agriculture. FRSL.
